page.title: 02Banwell Spring
page.content: Banwell spring is the fourth largest in the Mendip Hills and has never been known to fail. It gives approximately 2,300,000 gallons a day,rising to 7 million after heavy rain. Of this over 2 million goes to Weston and the rest flows into the River Banwell. Banwell village is supplied from Cheddar Resevoir and not from it's own spring. Around 1920 it was decided to cover in the spring. This difficult job was successfully carried out by an engineer,H.H.Brown. The concrete lining of the receiving tank was re-inforced with steel.The spring is connected to the Milton Road Pumping Station in Weston by a 16" mains pipe. The water, which in the past has been used in the manufacture of Bank of England notes and by a brewery, is exceptionally pure and only needs slight chlorination.
